perturbation.original_text: The Contract Term shall extend for a period of fifty (50) years. The date that the Business License is issued is the Establishment Date of the Joint Venture Company. Upon the agreement of all Parties and the unanimous consent of the Board of Directors, an application to extend the Contract Term may be made to the Examination and Approval Authority no less than six (6) months prior to the expiration of the Contract Term.
perturbation.changed_text: The Contract Term shall extend for a period of seventy-five (75) years. The date that the Business License is issued is the Establishment Date of the Joint Venture Company. Upon the agreement of all Parties and the unanimous consent of the Board of Directors, an application to extend the Contract Term may be made to the Examination and Approval Authority no less than one (1) month prior to the expiration of the Contract Term.
perturbation.explanation: Under Chinese law, specifically the Equity Joint Venture Law, the typical contract term for a joint venture is generally limited to a maximum of 50 years. Although longer terms are possible, they require special justification and approval, making a standard 75-year term non-compliant without specific legal grounds. Also, changing the application timeline for extension to one month goes against the typical legal requirements to provide ample notice for renewal.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Equity Joint Venture Law of the People's Republic of China; Regulations on Administration of Registration of Companies

perturbation.original_text: Following an application to dissolve the Joint Venture Company pursuant to Article 105, the Board of Directors shall forthwith appoint a liquidation committee which shall have the power to represent the Joint Venture Company in all legal matters. The liquidation committee shall value and liquidate the Joint Venture Company's assets in accordance with the applicable Chinese laws and regulations and the principles set forth herein.
perturbation.changed_text: Following an application to dissolve the Joint Venture Company pursuant to Article 105, the Board of Directors may, at their discretion, appoint a liquidation committee which shall have limited power to represent the Joint Venture Company in legal matters. The liquidation committee shall value and liquidate the Joint Venture Company's assets without strict adherence to Chinese laws and regulations.
perturbation.explanation: Chinese Company Law mandates a formal liquidation process under government supervision to protect creditor and employee interests. By making the appointment of a liquidation committee discretionary and undermining the adherence to Chinese law, the provision becomes non-compliant. Chinese liquidation laws requires strict adherence to legal processes.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Company Law of the People's Republic of China; Enterprise Bankruptcy Law of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text: If an event of Force Majeure occurs, a Party's obligations under this Contract affected by such an event shall be suspended during the period of delay caused by the Force Majeure and shall be automatically extended, without penalty, for a period equal to such suspension. The Party claiming Force Majeure shall promptly inform the other Party in writing and shall furnish within fifteen (15) days thereafter sufficient evidence of the occurrence and duration of such Force Majeure. The Party claiming Force Majeure shall also use all reasonable endeavours to terminate the Force Majeure.
perturbation.changed_text: If an event of Force Majeure occurs, a Party's obligations under this Contract shall be immediately terminated. The Party claiming Force Majeure shall, at their convenience, inform the other Party orally about the event. The Party claiming Force Majeure has no obligation to use any endeavors to terminate the Force Majeure.
perturbation.explanation: Under Chinese Contract Law, Force Majeure typically suspends contractual obligations, and parties are expected to mitigate the impact. Automatically terminating the contract and removing the obligation to provide evidence or mitigate the event contradicts the principle of good faith and the standard interpretation of Force Majeure clauses under Chinese law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law of the People's Republic of China
